title.value: A model-free approach for solving choice-based competitive facility location problems using simulation and submodularity
title.justification: The title of the paper is clearly mentioned in the beginning of the document and is representative of the content discussed throughout the paper.
title.quote: A model-free approach for solving choice-based competitive facility location problems using simulation and submodularity

extractions.description: This paper introduces a model-free approach to tackle choice-based competitive facility location problems by leveraging simulation and submodularity. It reformulates the problem into a maximum covering location problem, estimates preference profiles through simulation, and proposes a partial Benders decomposition for efficient solving. The solutions are compared to existing benchmark methods, showing improved performance under certain conditions.

type.justification: The paper develops a theoretical model-free approach that provides a framework for solving a class of optimization problems.
type.quote: We develop a theoretical analysis of our approach and show that the solution quality it provides for the original stochastic problem, its computational performance, and the automatic profile-retention strategy it exploits are directly connected to the entropy of the preference profiles in the population.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on solving facility location and optimization problems which falls under Operations Research.
name.quote: A model-free approach for solving choice-based competitive facility location problems using simulation and submodularity

name.justification: The paper involves solving optimization problems, specifically the maximum covering location problem.

name.justification: The paper uses simulation methods to handle the reformulated problem.
name.quote: ...simulating preference profiles through simulation generalizes a sample average approximation method...

name.justification: Submodularity is used in the reformulation process and is a key component of the proposed approach.
The paper reformulates the problem into a Maximum Covering Location Problem, which is thoroughly discussed in the content.
name.quote: ...results in a maximum covering location problem of manageable size.

is_contributed.justification: The MCLP is used as the reformulated model in the paper, not introduced as a novel contribution.
is_contributed.quote: ...results in a maximum covering location problem of manageable size.

is_executed.justification: The focus is on the reformulation and solving of problems theoretically rather than executing the model in practice.
is_executed.quote: ...results in a maximum covering location problem of manageable size.

is_compared.justification: The MCLP is not directly compared, rather the solution's effectiveness is discussed beyond typical comparisons with other models.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The MCLP is a well-known model introduced in literature, specifically referenced through Church and ReVelle's work.
referenced_paper_title.quote: This method approximates the utility function...formulated as a maximum covering location problem (MCLP) (Church and ReVelle, 1974)
